agents.name: exploit-critic
agents.description: Adversarial review that attempts to exploit code — finds injection, auth bypass, privilege escalation, and data exfiltration paths

agents.name: frontend-critic
agents.description: Reviews frontend code for component design, performance, styling, and best practices

agents.name: handoff-contract-critic

agents.name: network-critic
agents.description: Reviews code making network requests for resilience, blocking behavior, and lock-during-IO problems

agents.name: oddball-critic
agents.description: Reviews code for consistency with the existing codebase — flags patterns that look different from established conventions

agents.name: policy-testability-critic
agents.description: Flags non-testable MUST/CRITICAL/NEVER rules and suggests enforceable rewrites

agents.name: public-page-critic
agents.description: Reviews public-facing pages for conversion optimization, accessibility, mobile UX, and brand consistency

agents.name: quality-critic

agents.name: requirements-critic

opencode.description: OpenCode app configuration with MCP servers and defaults

workflows.description: How agents communicate and coordinate through asynchronous update queues

overview.summary: The toolkit uses a message-passing architecture where agents communicate through file-based update queues. This design keeps agents loosely coupled while enabling cross-agent collaboration. The user remains in control, deciding when to review and apply queued updates.
keyPrinciples: Agents never modify files outside their domain — they queue requests instead
Users decide when to apply updates, maintaining full control
Updates can be reviewed, modified, or rejected before application
Complex updates can be escalated to PRDs for proper planning

primaryAgents.description: The three entry-point agents users invoke directly

agents.name: planner
responsibilities: Bootstrap new projects with stack detection
Create and refine PRDs (Product Requirements Documents)
Manage the PRD registry and lifecycle states
Queue toolkit updates when discovering missing stack support

agents.name: builder
responsibilities: Build features from PRDs or ad-hoc requests
Queue toolkit updates when discovering workflow gaps

agents.name: toolkit
responsibilities: Maintain agents, skills, templates, and scaffolds
Process toolkit update requests from other agents
Queue project updates when schema or patterns change
Keep toolkit-structure.json and documentation in sync

updateQueues.description: File-based message queues for cross-agent communication

queues.name: pending-updates
queues.purpose: Toolkit improvement requests discovered during work
queues.description: When any agent discovers a gap in the toolkit — a missing pattern, outdated guidance, or needed enhancement — it writes a request file here instead of modifying toolkit files directly. This preserves separation of concerns while enabling continuous toolkit improvement.
workflow: Agent discovers toolkit gap during normal work
Agent writes structured request to pending-updates/
Agent notifies user: 'Queued toolkit update for @toolkit'
@toolkit presents pending requests at session start
User reviews each request and approves/rejects
queues.userControl: Users can review requests, ask clarifying questions, modify the scope, or reject updates entirely. Nothing is applied automatically.

example.scenario: Developer agent discovers Go import patterns aren't documented
example.outcome: @toolkit adds the pattern to coding-go.md template

queues.name: project-updates
queues.purpose: Project changes required by toolkit updates
queues.description: When toolkit changes require updates to existing projects — schema migrations, new required fields, or pattern changes — @toolkit queues instructions here. Each project has its own subfolder. @builder applies these updates when the user works on that project.
workflow: @toolkit makes a change that affects project structure
@toolkit writes update instructions for each affected project
@builder presents pending updates when user selects a project
User chooses to apply, defer, or skip each update
@builder delegates to @developer to apply the changes
@builder deletes the update file after successful application
queues.userControl: Users can apply updates immediately, defer them for later, or skip them entirely. Updates include verification steps so users can confirm correctness.

example.outcome: @builder updates each project's project.json to use new field name

escalationToPRD.description: When simple updates aren't enough, they become full PRDs
escalationToPRD.summary: Not all updates are simple fixes. When a pending update represents significant new functionality, architectural changes, or work that needs planning and decomposition, it can be escalated to a PRD.
triggers: Update requires multiple coordinated changes across the toolkit
Update introduces new concepts that need documentation and testing
Update affects multiple agents or skills in complex ways
User requests formal planning for a queued update
workflow: User reviews pending update and decides it needs more planning
User asks @planner to create a PRD from the update concept
@planner creates a proper PRD with stories and acceptance criteria
Original pending update is deleted (superseded by PRD)
@builder implements the PRD through normal workflow

example.scenario: Pending update requests 'add support for Rust projects'
example.reasoning: This requires new agents, templates, skills, and scaffold — too complex for a simple update
example.outcome: Escalated to PRD with stories for each component

userInitiatedUpdates.description: Users can also ask agents to generate pending updates
userInitiatedUpdates.summary: The update system isn't just for agent-discovered gaps. Users can ask any agent to queue an update request, capturing ideas for toolkit improvements without switching context.

examples.userRequest: Hey @developer, the way you handle database connections could be better. Queue an update for @toolkit to improve the guidance.
examples.agentAction: @developer writes a pending update describing the issue and suggested improvement
examples.outcome: User continues working; @toolkit addresses the improvement later

examples.userRequest: @builder, I want all my projects to use a new naming convention. Create a project update for each one.
examples.agentAction: @builder cannot create project-updates (only @toolkit can), so it queues a pending-update for @toolkit to handle
examples.outcome: @toolkit creates the project-updates in the next session

benefits: Capture improvement ideas without losing focus
Let the right agent handle the right work
Build a backlog of toolkit improvements organically

architectureDiagram.description: Visual representation of agent communication flow
ascii: │   (Reviews, approves, rejects, or escalates all updates)       │

marketingHighlights.description: Key value propositions for the website
marketingHighlights.headline: Autonomous Agents That Improve Themselves
marketingHighlights.subheadline: A self-evolving development system where agents discover gaps, queue improvements, and continuously enhance your workflow — all under your control.

valueProps.title: Self-Improving System
valueProps.description: Agents don't just follow instructions — they identify gaps and queue improvements. Your toolkit gets better every time you use it.
valueProps.detail: When @developer discovers an undocumented pattern or @builder hits a workflow limitation, they automatically queue an update for @toolkit. No more manually tracking 'things to fix later.'

valueProps.title: You Stay in Control
valueProps.description: Every update is queued, not applied. You review, approve, modify, or reject changes on your schedule.
valueProps.detail: Unlike systems that make changes autonomously, this toolkit respects your authority. Pending updates wait for your review. You can ask clarifying questions, scope down changes, or reject them entirely.

valueProps.title: Separation of Concerns
valueProps.description: Agents stay in their lane. Implementation agents don't modify the toolkit; toolkit agents don't touch your code.
valueProps.detail: @developer focuses on writing code, not maintaining agent definitions. @toolkit focuses on the agent system, not your application. Clear boundaries prevent accidents and make the system predictable.

valueProps.title: Asynchronous Collaboration
valueProps.description: Queue an idea now, address it later. Keep your flow while building a backlog of improvements.
valueProps.detail: Mid-implementation, realize the toolkit could handle something better? Ask the agent to queue an update. You don't lose context switching to @toolkit — the improvement waits for you.

valueProps.title: Graceful Escalation
valueProps.description: Simple fixes stay simple. Complex changes become proper PRDs with planning and decomposition.
valueProps.detail: A one-line fix stays a pending update. A new language stack? That escalates to a PRD with user stories, acceptance criteria, and proper implementation tracking.

useCases.title: Continuous Toolkit Evolution
useCases.story: You're building a feature when @developer mentions it doesn't have guidance for a pattern you're using. It queues an update. Next week, @toolkit presents the queue — 5 improvements discovered organically. You review and approve them. Your toolkit just got better without any dedicated 'maintenance time.'

useCases.title: Schema Migrations at Scale
useCases.story: @toolkit updates the project.json schema to add a new required field. It automatically queues migration instructions for all 12 of your projects. As you work on each project, @builder offers to apply the migration. No project gets left behind; no project is forced to update before you're ready.

useCases.title: Team Knowledge Capture
useCases.story: A team member discovers a gotcha with the database library. They tell @developer to queue a toolkit update. @toolkit adds it to the coding conventions. Now every future implementation — by any team member — benefits from that knowledge. Institutional memory, automated.

todoSynchronization.description: How primary agents keep right-panel todos and disk state synchronized for resumability
todoSynchronization.summary: Builder, Planner, and Toolkit treat OpenCode right-panel todos as the live checklist and mirror every status change to persistent state files. On startup, each agent restores panel todos from its state file so interrupted sessions can resume without losing task context.

flows.granularity: One todo per queued E2E test file
One todo per refinement task/question batch
One todo per planning update file
One todo per pending update file
One todo per user request task
One todo per mandatory post-change step

rules: Persist every todo transition with status and priority to the agent state file
Keep at most one in_progress todo at any time
Restore panel todos from state file on startup
Do not rely on memory-only todo tracking for resumable workflows
